column4: (Norbert Annu-2024)-Mixed public and church schools in three Slovak regions
column5: (Norbert Annu-2024)-Mixed methods: quantitative surveys + qualitative interviews + control group comparison
column6: (Norbert Annu-2024)-Learn with M.E. software used to personalize basic math instruction
column7: (Norbert Annu-2024)-Traditional teaching without the software
column9: (Norbert Annu-2024)-No standardized cognitive tests used; task accuracy logged in digital workbook
column10: (Norbert Annu-2024)-Likert-scale questionnaire on user motivation and experience
column11: (Norbert Annu-2024)-Student workbook logs, task performance database, teacher interviews
column12: (Norbert Annu-2024)-Descriptive statistics, frequency analysis, SPSS, user performance logs
column13: (Norbert Annu-2024)-Structured interviews, thematic content grouping, SWOT analysis
column14: (Norbert Annu-2024)-Convergent mixed-methods with control group comparison
column15: (Norbert Annu-2024)-Increased motivation and improved perceived understanding of math; personalized learning paths noted
column16: (Norbert Annu-2024)-No explicit effect size reported; software accuracy in error detection: 92%
column17: (Norbert Annu-2024)-Absence of standardized testing; no longitudinal tracking; some interface limitations
column18: (Norbert Annu-2024)-Improved calculation skills and understanding of operations, supported by adaptive task generation
column19: (Norbert Annu-2024)-Software helped identify and correct errors, aiding problem-solving practice
column20: (Norbert Annu-2024)-Trophies, gamification, and error feedback boosted student interest (82.3% enjoyed math more)
column21: (Norbert Annu-2024)-No data on anxiety, but students found software “motivating” and “fun”
column22: (Norbert Annu-2024)-Desktop app with personalized feedback, error recognition, trophy system, multilingual support
column23: (Norbert Annu-2024)-Perceived as effective by students and teachers; high engagement reported
column24: (Norbert Annu-2024)-Teacher training on interpretation of task logs; instructional support features like solution steps
column25: (Norbert Annu-2024)-Noted SES disparities in access/use preferences (e.g., Slovak vs. Hungarian vs. English language)
column26: (Norbert Annu-2024)-Suggests personalized digital tools with real-time feedback can support inclusive and adaptive math education.

column2: (Lida Asencio-2024)-Not explicitly stated for the main study, but survey involved 22 respondents (implied from percentages in Figs 13-21)
column3: (Lida Asencio-2024)-9 to 11 years old; Survey respondents aged 5-9 mostly
column4: (Lida Asencio-2024)-Children with difficulties in math/reading; Initial evaluation identified students with phonological/verbal memory issues for reading
column5: (Lida Asencio-2024)-Agile Scrum methodology used for development; Evaluation involved surveys and standardized tests comparing software users to traditional methods
column6: (Lida Asencio-2024)-Educational software with interactive games (Memorama, Sum game) and didactic exercises for basic math and reading comprehension
column7: (Lida Asencio-2024)-Traditional teaching methods
column9: (Lida Asencio-2024)-Standardized tests (details not specified), Entrance tests (phonological knowledge, verbal memory for reading)
column11: (Lida Asencio-2024)-N/A
column12: (Lida Asencio-2024)-Surveys analyzed using percentages
column15: (Lida Asencio-2024)-Notable improvement in performance for software users vs. traditional methods; Increased motivation and class participation observed
column16: (Lida Asencio-2024)-Not explicitly stated by authors, potential limitations mentioned in discussion include narrow age range initially targeted (6-8 planned, 9-11 studied) and lack of implemented inclusive learning methods
column17: (Lida Asencio-2024)-Software improved basic math skills (e.g., addition via Sum Game); Enhanced understanding through diverse resources and interactive exercises
column18: (Lida Asencio-2024)-Software designed to enhance problem-solving through interactive methods
column19: (Lida Asencio-2024)-Software aims to inspire students and increase motivation/participation through interactive games and didactic exercises; Survey showed positive reception of games (Memorama rated good/excellent by ~91%)
column20: (Lida Asencio-2024)-Software designed to address disinterest and distraction; Aims to make learning enjoyable
column21: (Lida Asencio-2024)-Interactive educational software (web system) developed using Visual Studio Code, HTML5, CSS3, JavaScript, SQL Server; Includes login, course access, Memorama (memory game), Sum game (addition)
column22: (Lida Asencio-2024)-Software users showed notable improvement compared to traditional methods; Positive user feedback on usability (login rated good/excellent by ~91%)
column23: (Lida Asencio-2024)-Software development involved educators; Principles included differentiated instruction and continuous assessment/feedback; Teachers can assign personalized exercises
column24: (Lida Asencio-2024)-Survey data suggests mothers and siblings are primary helpers at home; Significant connectivity issues hindered remote learning programs like "Aprendo en Casa" during pandemic; Computer most used device (54.5%), followed by cell phone (27.3%)
column25: (Lida Asencio-2024)-Project currently targets 9-11 years (study) but aims to expand; Inclusive learning methods not yet implemented; More mini-games planned
column26: (Lida Asencio-2024)-

column4: (Luca Cernigl-2021)-Children exceeding AAP screen time recommendations, no major developmental disorders
column5: (Luca Cernigl-2021)-Longitudinal, 3-wave observational study
column6: (Luca Cernigl-2021)-Daily use of smartphones and tablets for educational apps and short videos, assessed at age 4
column7: (Luca Cernigl-2021)-No control group (all participants exceeded AAP limits)
column8: (Luca Cernigl-2021)-Home (T0), school settings for teacher assessments (T1, T2)
column9: (Luca Cernigl-2021)-Teacher Report Form (TRF) Mathematics and Literacy T-scores
column10: (Luca Cernigl-2021)-Dysregulation Profile from TRF (Anxious/Depressed, Attention Problems, Aggression)
column11: (Luca Cernigl-2021)-StimQ-PIDA for parental scaffolding, SCL-90/R for maternal risk
column12: (Luca Cernigl-2021)-Pearson correlation, MANOVA, Structural Equation Modeling (SEM)
column13: (Luca Cernigl-2021)-Content-based group comparisons, no thematic coding reported
column15: (Luca Cernigl-2021)-Higher screen time at age 4 predicted dysregulation at ages 6 and 8; lower academic performance at age 8 only, mediated by dysregulation
column16: (Luca Cernigl-2021)-Standardized regression weights β = -0.34 to -0.57 for key paths; effect size η² = 0.34 (math at T2)
column17: (Luca Cernigl-2021)-No control group; maternal scaffolding not tracked over time; no direct cognitive testing
column18: (Luca Cernigl-2021)-Mathematics grades at age 8 were significantly lower in non-scaffolded group (M = 21.3 vs 28.1)
column19: (Luca Cernigl-2021)-No direct mention of computational thinking or structured problem-solving intervention
column20: (Luca Cernigl-2021)-Children with higher parental scaffolding showed significantly better engagement and emotional regulation at age 6
column21: (Luca Cernigl-2021)-Dysregulation at age 8 predicted by earlier screen time; indirectly linked to anxiety, withdrawal, attention issues
column22: (Luca Cernigl-2021)-Tablets and smartphones used for passive video watching and educational apps
column23: (Luca Cernigl-2021)-Tools less effective long-term without parental scaffolding; academic decline observed by age 8
column24: (Luca Cernigl-2021)-Scaffolding measured with PIDA subscale; higher PIDA scores correlated with better academic outcomes
column25: (Luca Cernigl-2021)-Lower-income families and mothers with less education showed higher screen time exposure in children
column26: (Luca Cernigl-2021)-Findings support that dysregulation mediates academic decline due to early excessive screen time; parental engagement delays but does not prevent cognitive/emotional impact

column1: (Buentello-Mo-2021)-Mexico, Taiwan, China, USA, Europe, Other (based on reviewed study origins )
column4: (Buentello-Mo-2021)-Varies across reviewed studies; some focused on low/high anxiety students, students with varying spatial visualization capabilities, or students with disabilities
column5: (Buentello-Mo-2021)-Systematic review of studies employing various designs (e.g., comparative, pre/post-test, surveys)
column6: (Buentello-Mo-2021)-Augmented Reality (AR) and Virtual Reality (VR) applications, AR books, virtual labs, visualization apps
column7: (Buentello-Mo-2021)-Traditional methods (e.g., traditional books), control groups without RETs, comparison between AR and VR
column9: (Buentello-Mo-2021)-Pre/post tests (PPT), specific tests for spatial thinking/visualization skills
column10: (Buentello-Mo-2021)-Satisfaction surveys (SS), Likert scales, Motivation scales, Math Anxiety measures
column11: (Buentello-Mo-2021)-Cronbach's Alpha, Factor analysis
column12: (Buentello-Mo-2021)-Comparison of test scores between groups, analysis of survey ratings
column14: (Buentello-Mo-2021)-Not explicitly stated for reviewed studies, but review combines quantitative and qualitative findings
column15: (Buentello-Mo-2021)-RETs generally accepted by students and show potential for improving performance and motivation, especially for abstract concepts and spatial skills. Effectiveness depends on adequate design.
column16: (Buentello-Mo-2021)-Performance improvement varied: e.g., 3-5% increase for low anxiety students, 25-31% for high anxiety students in specific areas; 36% higher pass rate in spatial skills for experimental group; 25% difference in geometry test scores; motivation/satisfaction increase around 13%.
column17: (Buentello-Mo-2021)-Hardware/software limitations; cost; potential for extraneous cognitive load; complicated usability/steep learning curve; need for adequate activity design; lack of teacher digital literacy/training; difficulty translating content effectively; lack of standardized measurement frameworks.
column18: (Buentello-Mo-2021)-RETs used to teach Geometry (GM), Calculus, Algebra, Vectors, Arithmetic, Probability. AR improved geometry performance (high anxiety students +31%, low anxiety +5%). AR apps helped understand concepts like multiple integrals  and vector operations. VR impacted visualization of partial derivatives. Focus on improving spatial visualization.
column19: (Buentello-Mo-2021)-RETs used to develop Spatial Thinking (ST). Apps transformed 2D graphs to 3D objects, visualized multivariable concepts, characterized parabolas, and allowed manipulation of vectors, improving spatial skills. No specific mention of problem-solving or computational thinking development.
column20: (Buentello-Mo-2021)-Increased Motivation (MT) and Interactivity (IN) were common goals. Students found RETs compelling, interesting, and useful. Studies aimed to increase engagement and curiosity, using interactivity to promote active learning. Motivation/satisfaction ratings increased.
column21: (Buentello-Mo-2021)-RETs used to ease learning (EL)  and reduce math anxiety. AR improved performance significantly for high anxiety students. Willingness to learn can increase by raising self-efficacy and reducing anxiety. Students reported better understanding with apps.
column22: (Buentello-Mo-2021)-Marker-based AR apps, AR books, mobile/tablet AR, computer-based AR/VR, Head-Mounted Displays (HMD) for high immersion VR, Kinect-based interaction, virtual labs/platforms, specific software like GeoGebra AR, Second Life, OpenSimulator.
column23: (Buentello-Mo-2021)-Students using RETs performed better than those using traditional books. AR shown to improve performance compared to control groups. AR particularly beneficial for high-anxiety students compared to low-anxiety ones. No statistical difference found between AR and VR user experience in one study.
column24: (Buentello-Mo-2021)-Adequate design of lectures/activities is crucial for RET success. Previous preparation/lecturing for both teachers and students is important, especially if RETs are initially found complicated. Need for teacher training due to potential lack of digital literacy and resistance. Instructional design should promote conceptual understanding over rote learning.
column25: (Buentello-Mo-2021)-Students' prior spatial visualization capabilities can affect outcomes. Student motivation and self-efficacy influence learning. Familiarity with technology can impact ease of use, though enthusiasm for training exists. Digital literacy levels of both students and teachers are factors. Geographic/economic factors mentioned as potential influences on research focus and resource availability (developing vs. developed countries).
column26: (Buentello-Mo-2021)-Review covers 2015-June 2020. 76% reviewed studies used AR, 16% VR, 8% mixed. Most studies used low immersion AR via mobile/tablet. Increasing trend in publications observed. Research often focuses on user acceptance/satisfaction rather than detailed learning metrics. Need for standardized frameworks to measure impact beyond novelty.

column20: (Andrea Guari-2023)-Psychological wellbeing significantly improved across both personal and school domains

column22: (Andrea Guari-2023)-Smartphone, internet, WhatsApp, radio/TV, educational materials, parental coaching

column24: (Andrea Guari-2023)-Weekly learning, teacher interaction, tech use showed positive gains; teacher contact critical
column25: (Andrea Guari-2023)-Children from low-education households and with younger siblings suffered greater losses
column26: (Andrea Guari-2023)-Comprehensive five-year dataset; highlights regressive impact of crisis and resilience of wellbeing.

column2: (Rocío Míngue-2024)-244 primary school students (80 no homework, 82 erroneous examples, 82 correct examples)

column6: (Rocío Míngue-2024)-4-week online homework intervention via Moodle platform with instructional videos (correct or erroneous examples) and interactive tasks (including GeoGebra number line applets) focusing on decimal number line concepts; approx. 15 min per homework session for 3 weeks after an initial on-site intro session
column7: (Rocío Míngue-2024)-Comparison groups: No homework condition; Correct examples homework condition; Erroneous examples homework condition

column11: (Rocío Míngue-2024)-Custom Moodle platform; Short instructional videos; GeoGebra applets
column12: (Rocío Míngue-2024)-ANCOVA, Planned Contrasts, Moderation Analysis (PROCESS macro in R), Johnson-Neyman technique, Effect Sizes (Cohen's d, r, η²p)
column15: (Rocío Míngue-2024)-Online homework improved decimal number line proficiency vs no homework, regardless of prior level. No overall difference between Correct/Erroneous examples, but Correct examples were significantly better for low-proficiency students
column16: (Rocío Míngue-2024)-Medium effect (r=0.36) for homework vs no homework; small effect (r=0.09) for correct vs erroneous examples overall
column17: (Rocío Míngue-2024)-Imprecise homework time tracking via Moodle; Short intervention duration; Focus only on decimal number line tasks; Need for research on other factors/longer interventions
column18: (Rocío Míngue-2024)-Online homework significantly improved proficiency in representing and identifying decimals on the number line (RNR, RR, INR, IR dimensions)
column19: (Rocío Míngue-2024)-Tasks involved number line representation/identification and estimation, not explicitly problem-solving or computational thinking
column20: (Rocío Míngue-2024)-Not measured; discussion suggests tailored, reasonably timed homework benefits engagement/attitude
column21: (Rocío Míngue-2024)-N/A
column22: (Rocío Míngue-2024)-Custom Moodle platform, interactive GeoGebra number line applets with feedback, short instructional videos (correct/erroneous examples)
column23: (Rocío Míngue-2024)-Online platform and GeoGebra applets effective for homework delivery and practice; Correct example videos more effective for low-proficiency students
column24: (Rocío Míngue-2024)-Homework designed based on common decimal misconceptions and pre-test results; differentiated instruction (correct/erroneous examples); importance of didactic planning emphasized
column25: (Rocío Míngue-2024)-Prior proficiency moderated impact (low-proficiency students benefit more from correct examples); conducted in Spain with 5th/6th graders
column26: (Rocío Míngue-2024)-Study supports online homework effectiveness for decimals; highlights interaction between instruction type (correct/erroneous examples) and prior knowledge; suggests tailoring homework to proficiency level

column4: (A L Voievoda-2024)-School students in Ukraine (Vinnytsia, Chernivtsi regions) and Israel (Kiryat Yam); Mixed gender; Post-COVID digitalization context
column5: (A L Voievoda-2024)-Comparative survey research using questionnaires and statistical analysis (phi-Fisher criterion)
column6: (A L Voievoda-2024)-Examines student opinions/experiences with existing digital mathematical games (e.g., Matific, Kahoot)
column7: (A L Voievoda-2024)-Comparison between Ukraine and Israel student groups; Implicit comparison to traditional teaching methods
column8: (A L Voievoda-2024)-School mathematics education context (Ukraine/Israel); Online data collection
column9: (A L Voievoda-2024)-Questionnaire assessing awareness and perceived knowledge gain from games; Literature review on cognitive impacts
column10: (A L Voievoda-2024)-Questionnaire assessing interest, desire for use, perception as fun/useful vs. waste of time; Literature review on motivation/anxiety
column11: (A L Voievoda-2024)-Questionnaire (demographics, usage frequency, teacher use, specific games, open-ended opinions); phi-Fisher statistical test
column12: (A L Voievoda-2024)-Frequency analysis (% of responses); phi-Fisher test for statistical significance of differences between groups
column13: (A L Voievoda-2024)-Analysis of open-ended responses on opinions/vision; Identification of commonly used games; Summary of challenges
column14: (A L Voievoda-2024)-Combination of quantitative survey data/statistics and qualitative analysis of open responses/context
column15: (A L Voievoda-2024)-High student interest in both countries, but lower reported teacher usage (esp. Ukraine); Statistically significant differences in usage frequency, teacher implementation, and preference for traditional methods between countries; Popular games identified
column16: (A L Voievoda-2024)-Statistical significance of differences reported using phi-Fisher criterion, but effect sizes not explicitly stated
column17: (A L Voievoda-2024)-Underdeveloped methodology, need for teacher training, curriculum integration challenges, technical infrastructure, classroom management issues, risk of addiction
column18: (A L Voievoda-2024)-Students generally admit games can be useful, but some doubt effectiveness; Literature suggests positive cognitive impacts (knowledge, perception, memorization, fewer errors)
column19: (A L Voievoda-2024)-Not primary focus; Literature mentions problem-solving elements and representational transformation in some games
column20: (A L Voievoda-2024)-High student interest and desire to use games reported; Seen as potentially more engaging than traditional methods, especially online; Some view games purely as entertainment
column21: (A L Voievoda-2024)-Literature review mentions potential for math anxiety reduction and benefits for low self-efficacy students
column22: (A L Voievoda-2024)-General digital mathematical games; Specific examples: Matific, Kahoot, Ten Fingers, mathPlayground, Minecraft; MATH-DIGGER (escape room) cited in literature
column23: (A L Voievoda-2024)-Student interest high; Higher teacher usage reported in Israel; Literature cites evidence for effectiveness but effectiveness depends on proper use; Some student skepticism exists
column24: (A L Voievoda-2024)-Strong need identified for teacher training and methodological guidance; Curriculum integration and alignment with learning outcomes crucial; Classroom management and game design quality are factors
column25: (A L Voievoda-2024)-Compares two national contexts; Considers gender (literature review notes effects); Technical infrastructure availability matters; COVID-19 accelerated digital adoption
column26: (A L Voievoda-2024)-Gap between student interest and teacher implementation noted; Games should supplement traditional methods

column2: (Melva Zainil-2024)-199 (99 in experimental group, 100 in control group)
column4: (Melva Zainil-2024)-Elementary school students
column5: (Melva Zainil-2024)-Quasi-experimental design with pretest-posttest control group
column6: (Melva Zainil-2024)-STEM-based digital learning model
column7: (Melva Zainil-2024)-Conventional STEM learning
column9: (Melva Zainil-2024)-6C Skills assessment tool measuring character, citizenship, critical thinking, creative thinking, collaboration, and communication
column11: (Melva Zainil-2024)-N/A
column12: (Melva Zainil-2024)-ANOVA and multivariate analysis
column15: (Melva Zainil-2024)-Significant improvement in all 6C skills in the experimental group compared to the control group; strong statistical significance (p=0.000) across all dimensions
column16: (Melva Zainil-2024)-Large effect sizes with R² values ranging from 0.479 to 0.866 for different skills
column17: (Melva Zainil-2024)-Short study duration limiting long-term impact assessment; need for longitudinal research
column18: (Melva Zainil-2024)-STEM-based digital learning improved critical thinking by 15.62 points (89.86 vs 74.24) and creative thinking by 14.72 points based on standardized 6C skill assessments.
column19: (Melva Zainil-2024)-STEM activities enhanced problem-solving through collaborative project-based tasks showing 12.32 point improvement in collaboration scores.
column20: (Melva Zainil-2024)-Students showed increased engagement with interactive STEM simulations and real-world problem scenarios according to teacher observations.
column21: (Melva Zainil-2024)-No direct mention of anxiety reduction or emotional responses.
column22: (Melva Zainil-2024)-Used a digital platform integrating science experiments, math modeling, engineering challenges, and technology tools.
column23: (Melva Zainil-2024)-STEM-based digital learning showed statistically significant superiority over conventional methods in all 6C dimensions (p=0.000).
column24: (Melva Zainil-2024)-Teacher training on digital STEM tools was provided but specific impact metrics not reported.
column25: (Melva Zainil-2024)-No socioeconomic factors were specifically analyzed in the study.
column26: (Melva Zainil-2024)-The study recommends longitudinal research to observe long-term 6C skill development and suggests expanding implementation to more diverse contexts.
